subject: Data
title: Sampling: How Asking a Few Tells About Millions
description: A 60-second lesson on Sampling: How Asking a Few Tells About Millions.

hook.text: A poll of 1,000 Americans can predict the opinions of 330 million. How is that possible?

buildup.text: Statistical sampling says a well-chosen subset mirrors the whole population â€” within a known margin of error.

discovery.text: The key is randomness. Every person must have an equal chance of being selected for the sample to work.

twist.text: In 1936, Literary Digest polled 2.4 million people and got the election wrong. Gallup polled 50,000 and won.

climax.text: The Digest's sample was biased toward wealthy phone owners. Sample size matters less than sample quality.

punchline.text: Ask the right few and you'll know what millions think.

quiz.question: Why did Literary Digest's massive 1936 poll fail?
options: The sample was biased toward wealthy respondents
